div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

MONDAY, FEBRUARY. 4, 1907

div.head: MORTGAGES IN EGYPT.
div.p: DR. EID'S REPORT.

Having established his major premise, and having fixed the percentage of the mortgage debt at 8.9 %, Dr. Eid next turns his attention to the effect and influences of a mortgage debt on the economical development of the country.

The economical development of Egypt owes its birth to Mehemet Ali and much of its subsequent growth to the Khedive Ismail who for all his extravagances must be reckoned in many ways economically as a factor for good in Egyptian agricultural history: the first barrage and many of the major canals of today are standing witness of his endeavours and successes.
But when the inevitable crash came its ultimate result was to break up the large holding in course of time we have already explained in dealing with the Dumsins and Daira Sanit)

and to put them in the hands of the most proper owners. the actual titles of the sol , who like the yeomen of old-time in England may truly be considered the backbone of the country. To the number of these who became proprietors on the breakdown of Ismail finances must now be added all who have bought land from the Credit Foucier and those other institutions that obtained barren land from the Government converted it into agricultural properties, and re-sold it at a comfortable profit. So that to-day as compared with 80 years ago the number of peasant proprietors is enormous. It is profitable therefore to cor aider if thia large body of persons receive a benefit or the reverse from the money they borrow on mortgage.
In the consideration of the utility of a low two facts must be borne in mind : —
1. Will the money be in sumptuary expenses?
2. Will the harden of the loan exceed the benefits to be derived from it?

To the first of these questions we can answer at once in the negative. The country does not lend itself to extravagances as such as the formation of gardens, pleasure perks and similar schemes, and still more the inherent nature of the native is opposed to extravagance, the are schemed for farther reclamation in the fellah being noted for his almost simple future in the almost unknown territory in the city and habits of life and harmony when he Sudan and elsewhere, and the day that sees has any to spare is all put back into his own those schemes turned to realities will also see and or employed in the purchase of land of Egypt in a position to triple her present his neighbors.

To answer the second question we must first decide the average rate of interest co mortgage money, end as not even the banks publish this it is difficult to fix it accurately. The conventional maximum in Egypt is 9% and the Agricultural bank, which charges the highest rate owing to the smallness its loans and the comparative shortness of their duration, bee now dropped it. rate from 9% to 8%. But on ventes e teime the rate probably varies from 4% to 5%. Dr. Eid, after careful consideration, fixes on the following rate, as forming the average rate, to-day: 6.2% for the Bank., 5 for assurance end other companies, 8 for private individuals, and 5 for rentes & tormer, whereas in 1895 the average rate was. at least 8% all round. If then, as is the cure, the amount of the mortgage debt daring s leal ten years baa increased by 254% the amount paid as charges thereon has only shown an increase of 194%. 'Meanwhile daring those years the exports of the country, well called 'lo miroir par excellence do dere'opment doouomiqae," shows an increase of 70%. while all the time taxation of all aorta has been diminishing.

But possibly ell these generalisations ate not applicable to any given cases. Let us therefore take the example of a total mortgage effected first by the proprietor of a email holding of 5-feddans and second of a somewhat larger holding of say 50 feddans and let us see how heavily the burden of high debt weighs upon the mortgager, In the first place, to replace moneys by the produce of the soil takes at least 15 years and that that is fully recognised is shown by the fact that the Agricultural Bank lately advanced its maximum period from 15 to 20 years and that the average duration,of a loan granted by the other banks is 19 years.

Now let us assume the value of our land at L.E. 100 a feddan, giving in the first instance a total of L.E. 500 On this the banks will advance up to 60 % of its value, say, LE 300, end putting the rate at its highest, let us say at 7 % plus l. % for expenses. To repay this in 15 years, Dr. Eid estimates will require an amortisation fund of LE 28 to L.E 34 per annum, and as the soil in Egypt gives a return of at least 7 % our tellah mortgager makes LE 35 per annum and at the same time lives off his land. Thus at the end of 15 years he will stand quit of his debt with a minimum of £15 set aside, and during those fifteen years it must not be forgotten that he has supported himself and bit family on the produce of the lend, besides making some profit on what we may call bye-products such as milk, eggs, chickens, goats and the like, which are mainly self-supporting and find their own sustenance at best they can. In troth, LB. 15 in. 15 years - is not wealth, but for the Egyptian peasant it is as far removed from destination as it is from riches according to the European standpoint. Finally we mast remember that at the end of the period he 'is possessed of a property improved to the value of the mortgage money sank therein and of 15 years' constant labor spent thereon.

The larger the property the greater the amount that can be putby; for the interest is refunded and the term extended as that our proprietor of 50 feddene cf similar value on a total mortgage amounting to somewhere between LE 8,500 and LE 3 000 at 7 % all told would have to set aside an amortisation fund of be tween L.E 235 and LE 280 per annum, and would gain from his laud L.E 350, leaving the comparatively comfortable margin of L.E. 70 to LE 115 per annum. And as a further proof that the fellaheen are not weighed down by a burden of debt,a study of the number of expropriations renders the matter quite clear. In 1897 those amounted to 266. while in 1905 bey were but 110 and of these the majority represent the results of the execution of judge -ments given in transactions other than mortgage transactions.

Finally Dr. Eid draws hit conclusions from all these carefully compiled and well-arranged statistics. The mortgage debt of Egypt is lower io proportion than that of any other civilised country, and that not withstanding the fact that from the fertility of its soil Egypt is fitted to boar an unusually heavy mortgage debt without inconvenience But the time, Dr. Eid thinks, has now come to pause a little and consolidate what is already under cultivation, rather than seek to extend the area of fertility ; and that the Government think alike with Dr. Eid on this point is proved by 'be fact that the water0 the main or sole source of Egypt's fertility—is now being employed in improvements rather than in extensions and in perfecting whet is already began rather than in attempting any new undertakings. But this period of consolidation, we are told, though necessary, need not be of long duration, and already vast projects.

div.head: Plague Credit
div.p: The Public Health Department has applied for a credit of L.E. 10,000 to fight the plague in Egypt

div.head: New Foundlings' Home.
div.p: The Wak's Administration has allotted L E. 6,000 of Wakfe revenae for the creation of a. new foundlings' home in Cairo.

div.head: The Artesian Boring and Prospecting Co.
div.p: We learn that this company, which is in­creasing its capital to £100.000 by a new issue, has secured the services of Mr. F. M. Binger, manager of the Bank of Salonica, as a member of its board.

div.head: Stabbing Affray.
div.p: In the course of a drunken brawl in the Attarin quarter yesterday between three Ar­menians, one of them stabbed the two others. One of his victims, a British subject, is not expected to live

div.head: Village Murder.
div.p: Our Damanhour Correspondent telegraphs' that the agent of Boghos Pasha Nubar was murdered yesterday at Markib village. Two Europeans have been arrested on suspicion of being the authors of the crime.

div.head: Coal Imports.
div.p: For the month of January, the total import of coal into Alexandria was 61,468 tons, made up as follows : — Welsh, 29,373 ; Newcastle, 17,637 ; Scotch, 2,474 ; Yorkshire, 8,427 ; other qualities, 3,557. Daring January 1906 the total was 71,655 tons.

div.head: Benefit Performance.
div.p: A special performance of 'Tosca' wiil be given at the Zizinia Theatre on Sunday next in aid of the Italian free night schools. The performance will be under the patronage of the Italian Consul-General. The programme will include the "Danza delle Ore" from "Gioconda " snakes

Yesterday afternoon, at the Ibrahimieh Pi geon Shooting Club, a large cobra was killed. When measured it was found to be 1 metre 80 cm. long, and about 14 or 15 cm. at the thickest part of its body. This is the third large cobra which has been killed in that district within recent date.

div.head: All Saints' Church, Ramleh.
div.p: Aba meeting of voters held on the 2nd inst., the Rev. E. H. Blyth, at present Chaplain at Suez, was appointed Chaplain of All Saints,' Ramleh, from 1st May next. At the same meeting Messrs. G.B. Alderson, H. B. F. Park inson, and H. Swinglehurst were reelected on the committee for 1907.

div.head: Sleeping Care.
div.p: The Egyptian State Railways announce that, commencing from Sunday, 10th February, until further notice, the sleeping-car service on Cairo-Alexandria night trains Nos. 33 and 34, leaving Cairo and Alexandria at 1130pm., respectively, will be suppressed. First-clsss passengers can, however, hire pillows and blankets at a cost of 10 piastres for the journey by these trains.

div.head: Damanhour Industrial School.
div.p: A committee has been formed at Damanhour to collect funds for the industrial school which i Prince Hussein Pasha Kamel has proposed to create there The members of the committee are Ibrahim Bey Nassar, wekil of the Daira of the Prince ; Mohamed Bey El Miniawi, and Mohamed Bey Wakil, notables of Damanhour. The following subscriptions have been re­ceived : — Boghos Pasha Nobar, £1 000 ; M. George Eid, £500 ; M. Nestor Gianaclis, £500 ; the Belgian company managed by M. Eid, £400 ; Ahmed Bey Cherif, £400 ; Messrs. Selim and Simaan Sednaoni, £300 ; Frad Pasha Izzet, £150 ; Aziz Pasha lrzat, £150.

div.head: Ambassador and Chancellor.
div.p: The most distinguished of early British diplomatists, Sir Henry Wotton, Kt. (1568- 1639), whilst passing through Germany on his way to Venice and staying at Augsburg, wrote in his post's album the following definition :

" Legatos est vir bonus, peregre missus ad mentiendum Reipublicae; causa:" intended, as he tells us in his autobiography, to be English as follows : "An Ambassador is an honest man sent to lie abroad for his country's good," a definition capable of two interpretations in English, hut only one in the original. The long telegram, published on Saturday, describing the interview in Germany of Mr. Stead, re­minds us of a less-known aphorism of Sir Henry : "A Chancellor is a deceitful man kept at home for the purpose for which an Am- basador is sent abroad."

div.head: OBITUARY
div.p: G.. VIVIAN VERNON.

It is with sincere regret that we have to record the death of Mr. G. Vivian Vernon. Mr. Vernon first came to Egypt between seven and eight years ago, when he was on the staff of Sir John Aird and Co. On the completion of the works at Assouan Mr. Vernon com menced business in Alexandria, and for the last two years be had been manager and director of the British Engineering Company. His death occurred on Saturday at the Deaconesse Hospital, after a long and painful illness. His death, at the early age of 38, will be regretted by a wide circle of friends. The funeral took yesterday, the service being conducted by the Rev. A.H. Longley.

div.head: DEATH.
div.p: WALKER.—On 2nd February, at her residence, 9, rue Geser Pasha, the widow of the late William Walker, of Constantinople, and mother of Miss
G F. Walker, Alexandria, aged 70

div.head:
FEHIM PASHA.
TERRORISING CONSTANTINOPLE
div.p: Baron Marschall de Beiberstein was received in audience by the Sultan. The crimes of Fehim Pasha were the chief subject of the conversation, and as a result his Majesty has ordered the formation of a special com- mission at Yildiz to examine the chargee. Fehim Pasha has become an object of terror to everybody. In the meanwhile he parades the city ostentatiously. (Reuter)

It is with a certain measure of relief that we hear of the action taken by the German Em­bassy at Constantinople to punish Fehim Pasha chief of the Hafirh. Thia functionary has thus far enjoyed immunity owing to the fact of his being son of the foster-brother of the Sultan, and therefore a privileged bosom ser- pent. A worthy successor of Ghani Bey, whose oppressions are recorded in Mr. Holme Beaman's interesting book on the Near East, Fehim has been, and is still,, the object of the hatred and terror of all Turkish subjects. His gor­geous carriage, with its yellow upholstery, is one of the sights of Pera as it rolls swiftly down the Grande Roe, with his Ex­cellency seated pompous'y in it—a fat and short man with a decidedly unpleasant cast of countenance. His rival at Coart is Nejib Melbame (or Malfame, to quote a Perote nick­name) and both have distinguished them­selves by their seal in hatching and revealing the same plots ! Fehim is more daring than the conning Syrian ; possibly because he feels himself more secure. Twice, at night, he has striven to get sympathy at Yildiz by the singularly risky method of dropping from this same gorgeous vehicle a bomb timed to ex­plode when his person was sufficiently removed from danger. This served another purpose. It was intended to prove the existence of conspiracy, to* discover which Fehim and Mal- fame had received a commission. Malfame was the first to be commissioned. He miraculously unearthed a nest of bombs and conspirators and after ransacking every nook and corner, he assured the Sultan that he might repose in absolute tranquillity. This would not do for Fehim, who, to upset the Saltan's confidence in his rival, resorted to the barbarous method above described. Perhaps it was a coincidence, but strange to relate the outrages presumably attempted on his person took place soon after the mysterious removal from Top Hana of several of the bombs which Malfame had found. Q E D. It remains to be seen what punishment the Saltan will mete oat to his foster son, to appease the wrath of the in­dignant German Elchi—possibly some promo­tion to the provinces and a subsequent restora­tion to Imperial favour.

div.head: A YOUNG TURK
div.p: The ' Mokattam" announces that Sherif Pat-ha, Ottoman Minister at Stockholm, now in Cairo, is suspected of being a Young Turk, and has received orders to quit the Egyptian capital at once. The Pasha has been in Cairo for three months.

div.head: LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL
div.p: The Legislative Council met on Saturday morning under the presidency of Abdul Hamid Pasha Sadik and after debate submitted to a committee the draft of the law for the Eastern Desert. This committee is composed of Mo-hamed Pasha Olwi, Ibrahim Pasha Said Ismail Pasha Abez Ahmed Pasha Yebya, and Aly Pasha Charawi. The Khedivial decree was the read appointing Mohamed Pasha Olwi and Morkas Bey Semeika permanent members of the Council. The Council decided to publish and distribute the draft law relative to the remodelling of the Mehkemeh Sharieh. The next meeting is fixed for the 20th inst.

div.head: THE SEASON UP-RIVER.
div.p: Assouan has never had a more brilliant season than the present. For the last week the three hotels of the Upper Egypt Hotels conference have been full, and, judging by the numerous orders coming in daily, will remain so' for some time to come. There are 320 visitors staying at the Cataract Hotel, 80 at the Savoy, and 120 at the Grand Hotel. The hotels at Luxor belonging to the same company are doing just as well, and the new Winter Palace Hotel, although only newly opened, is already overbooked. Among the visitors staying at Assouan are Sir Wllliam and Lady Ewart and family, Comte de Bruges and suite, Comte and Comtesse Inards, Countess von Henckel Donuersmatk, and Countess Hahn. Among the latest arrivals at the Winter Palace, Luxor, are M. Achille Fould and Baroness de Forest and suite, Sir Hamilton Lang and party, etc. The passengers for Upper Egypt by the train de luxe on Saturday were Mr. Blunt, Mr. Edde, Mr. Hughes, Mr. Sapline, Mr. Brookfield, Mr. Chapman, Mr. Sadler, Mr. Sellear, Mr. Bendall, Mr. and Mrs Durand, Mr. and Mrs. Town- send, Mr. Ambrosano.

Count Wachmesiter, the new Swedish Di­plomatic Agent at Cairo, who is at present in Alexandria, has paid an official visit to the acting Governor of Alexandria, accompanied by the Swedish Vice-Consul.

div.head:
THE POST OFFICE FRAUDS
AN ARREST AT ALEXANDRIA
div.p: Yesterday, an interesting development oc­curred in the startling case of the forgery of foreign money orders through the Egyptian Post Office. When the Florio-Rubattino S.S. Singapore arrived at Alexandria from Naples it was boarded by the Alexandria police, who at once arrested one of the passengers, on the charge of having acted as accomplice on the continent of Europe in farthering the machina tions of the person who styled himself "George Bey,'' in attempting to enoash money orders to the extent of £20,000. The man, when seized by the police, gave his name as Zinos Velis.

The history of the discovery of this fraud is very interesting, and reflects great credit on the Egyptian Postal Administration for so promptly following up the matter. A telegram was received last week at the General Post Office at Alexandria from the post office at Milan announcing the arrival of an unusual number of foreign money orders from Egypt and asking whether they were to be cashed. This telegram was followed by others sent from the postal authorities at Rome, Brussels, and Berne couched in similar terms. The issue of the orders was stated to have taken place on the 22nd ulto.

The Postmaster General thereupon entrusted Borton Bey with a mission of enquiry, and that official left for Cairo on Thursday. It was discovered that there had been a most serious fraud committed, for the European post offices had wired the serial numbers of the money orders. Farther enquiries pointed to a certain Georgiadis, a clerk in the Cairo post office, as being the guilty party It was found that he was nominally on sick leave at Helouan. When his whereabouts were sought after there no trace of him was discovered. Telegrams were then sent to the Italian General Post Office at Rome with orders to arrest such a man, as he was presumably following the money orders in order to encash them. A telegram was received at the General Post Office at Alexandria on Friday night announcing that the Italian authorities had effected the arrest at Naples of a man of the name of "George Bey." Further telegrams arrived here on Saturday from Naples stating that the man, who bad been arrested, had admitted that his real name was Georgiadis, and that he was a postal clerk at Cairo.

A number of the money orders bad been ad­dressed to a certain Zanos, and another official enquiry was opened to discover the whereabouts of this person, but this was cleared up by a telegram from Italy to the effect that a man of that name had embarked , on the Fiorio-Rubattino S.S. Singapore, which was due to arrive at Alexandria yesterday; The arrest was effected, as we have announced, and as Zanos is a local subject be was handed over to the Egyptian authorities and interro- gated by the Parquet this morning. He admitted to the Parquet that he was employed by Georgiades.
Georgiadis, who is a Hellenic subject, bears an excellent character in his official capacity,
and was recognised as a quiet, respectable, hard-working postal employe.

The total amount involved was £20,000 and it is satisfactory to know that nothing has been paid over. The fraud was executed on the 23rd ulro. and by yesterday, the 3rd inst., both the men implicated were in gaol in various parts of the world. The Egyptian postal authorities are to be congratulated on the celerity with which they followed up the indications they received from Europe.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Among the passengers who arrived by the Hohenzollern to day were Lord Faber, Baron de Zoylen de Nyevelt,Baron George de Reuter, Comte de Gramedo, Mr. and Mrs. Leigh Hunt, Col. Maberley, etc..
Count and Countess Caprara arrived from Europe yesterday by the Florio Rubattino steamer.

Sir Ernest Cassel entertained a few friends at dinner yesterday evening at the Savoy. Among the guests were: Harari Pasha add Mme Harari, Mrs. Scrinburne, Mrs. Cassel Sir Benjamin Baker, Baron Heintse, Mr. Clayton, Mr. Lawrence, Mr. Horschitz. and Mr. Marx
Sir Ernest Cassel is leaving Cairo this evening for Upper Egypt.
Sir H. Pinching, Direotor General of the Public Health Department, will* probably represent the Egyptian Government at the International Conference to be held at Berlin in September next.
Sir Walter Mieville, K.C.M.G., left Alexandria by the midday express to-day en route for Khartoum, accompanied by Simond Bey.
The salary of M. P. Bernardi, Khedivial Counsellor at the Contentieux of the Ministry of the Interior, has been increased to LE 1,750, to date from January 1.
A special tram will leave Bulkley for Alexandria. stopping at all stations, at 2 a.m., after Mrs. Percy Carver's dance to-morrow night.

div.head: SAVOY HOTEL.
div.p: SATURDAY'S FESTIVITIES.

Few outside invitations had been issued for Saturday's dance at the Savoy; but the house is so crowded, and there were such a number of dinner parties arranged for that night, that the ball-room and lounge were patronized to their full later on in the evening. Every available table was occupied in the dining-room and restaurants, the overflow being accommodated in the covered-in verandah. Sir Ernest Cassel was one of the hosts of the evening, having Lady Newborough and Mrs. Cassel among his party. Mrs. Leverioh had a large party, and among the other hosts were Dr. Tribe, Mr. and Mrs. Cochrane, Mr. Phillipson, Mrs. and Miss Bennett, Count and Countess Hellnstein, Biron Pfyffer, Baron Bleich-iTfor, Baron Biederman, M. and Mme Cordonier, Mr. and Miss Pooley, Mr. Wigham, etc. The sexett orchestra discoursed very gentle music during the dinner hour, and the Ladies' Orchestra did their duty bravely during the remainder of the evening. The latter has improved wonderfully daring the last few weeks, and if most people will insist upon waltzes which grow faster and faster, there are many dancers now who are learning the charm of a slow dance to a quick measure.

Never this season have so many beautiful frocks been seen at the Savoy; and one wonders whether the ladies of Cairo have pondered to some purpose over the saying of one of our habitnes, that every one should on her arrival look away at least two of her best dresses and forget all about them till the 1st of February Certainly every frock almost on Saturday looked fresh enough to give colour to the sunrise and many of them were of quite the best frock order. No one looked better than the Countess of Hellnstein in a wonderful dress of yellow draped with fine lace about the shoulders,which lace hung in long ends from the back of the elevated waist line. Her high coiffure was crowned with an enormous bunch of paradis in pale yellow and white, a form of decoration to which she is much addicted. Lady Newboroogh was wearing a lovely frock of pink satin edged with a flowing line of diamentee lace and velvet. The draped corsage was a mass of glittering jewels and sequins, and she wore a bunch of pink osprey in her hair. Mrs. Charlton also wore a lovely dress of lace made over and trimmed with pale grey satin, and Miss McKellar's dress of yellow chiffon, bearing many frills and insertions and trimmings of guipure d'lrelande, was most dainty and attractive Mrs. Carey, with her beautiful white hair, looked her best in a dress of black lace over white with bretelles and trimming of turquoise velvet her ermine scarf adding the finishing touch to a charming toilette. Mme Sursock was in cream satin much embroidered with passementerie and bearing a deep hem of pink velvet embroidered with gold. Her pretty daughter was in yellow with a gold fillet in her hair. Mrs Wain was with her two daughters,the eldest looking very well in a plain princess frock of yellow satin, and Miss Blythe locked extremely handsome in a beautiful frock of pale green. Miss Shaw had on a dainty frock of spotted net over pale pink, many garlands of pink ribbon ruching trimming both skirt and bodice, and Miss Molloy was in a dress of grey chiffon taff tas. he soft corsage being of much betneked chiffon of the same shade. Mrs. Rome had on an embroidered black lace dress over pale blue, and Mrs. Wilding's dress of black had many stripes of dark blue iridescent embroidery upon it. Mrs. Wynne was in a soft gown of cream with incrustations of silver embroidery, and Miss Leverich was also in cream, her satin frock being trimmed with insertions of diamentee lace. Mrs. Armstrong, who is chaperoning the two Miss de Vahls this season, was in a handsome gown of grey velvet, while the Miss de Vahls wore pretty pompadeur and pink chene silk respectively. Mrs. Stout's dress of thick lace edged and trimmed with blue velvet was much admired. Mrs. Nungovicb, who arrived late, was wearing a magnificent toilette of golden tissue oyer which was a robe of embroidered chiffon, and Miss Nungovich was in the daintiest of lace frocks softly gleaming with mother-of-pearl pailettes and embroidered with pink roses. Miss Hurley was in pale blue with a glittering bolero and bows of black; and one Miss York was also in pale blue, while the second was wearing a most becoming frock, of emerald green chiffon outlined with narrow bands of green sequins, and with golden tassels hanging from the sleeves and also from the fillet in her hair.

Among the other ladies present were Mrs. Rom, in grey, Mrs. Stone and Miss Lusk, in black, Miss Lyon Campbell, in diamentee cream satin, Miss Joseph, in yellow, Miss Pooley, in grey, Miss Doffin, in blue, Miss Coles, in pink, Mrs. Bayley, Miss Crofton, Miss Carey, Mrs. Spong, Mrs. Weldor, Mrs. Saunders, Mrs. Howell, Mrs. Schreiber, Miss Morritt, Mrs. Peach, and many others of which time and space forbid farther mention.

div.head: ROUMANIAN STEAMER ASHORE.
div.p: The Roumanian Company's S.S. Priucipessa Maria, which plies between Constanza and Smyrna, went ashore at Tenedos, but was towed off by the same company's S.S. Rou- mauia, which left Alexandria on Thursday last. The vessel sustained damage which will require two mouths' repairs.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Cunard S.S. sailed direct for Liverpool on Saturday afternoon . lull car,go, including 3,187 bales cotton.

div.head:
GHEZIREH PALACE.
A SUCCESSFUL DANCE.
div.p: Ghezireh Palace Hotel has more than its usual complement of smart visitors this year, and the dance on Thursday evening attracted many of the residents in the neighbourhood as well as a goodly assortment from Cairo. Many came as dinner guests, Mr. Yorke having a party of eight and Mr. Gosohen one of ten. Mr. Curphey, Sir Hugh and Lady Smiley, Mrs Morcom, Mr. and Mrs. Ritz, Baron and Baronne de Pfyffer, and Mrs. Carey also had guests, and Mrs. and Miss Crofton were cele- brating their arrival in company with Mr. and Mrs. Hadow. At another table were being enter- tained Mme. Reyntian and her son, Me. and Mme. Bazil, Miss Ami, Mrs. Maclean, Mme. Agaion. Mile, de Codt, Mr. Priolean, Mr. Fox, and Mr. Irwin, while Mrs. Howell's party included Mrs. Stanley Bird, Miss Mo- Kellar, Lord Royston, the Hon. Claude Yorke, and Mr. G. W. Bennett.

The beautiful lounge was a brilliant sight daring the interval between dinner and the dance : the many uniforms of the soldiers pre sent adding their quota to the general effect. There were almost too many people present for the ball-room ; but no one minds sitting out at Ghezireh, where there are so many cosy corners and such delightful surroundings. Mr. Machell and Lady Valda Machell were noticed in the hall; and the Hon. Mr. and Mrs. Findlay were also present. Sir Thomas Wrightson was also seen chatting with his friends; and Mrs. and Miss Crofton were being eagerly greeted by their friends : for they are both very popular, and Miss Crofton has the reputation for being a beautiful dancer. Mrs. Carey was chaperoning her daughter and Miss F x ; and

Mrs. Leverich was also there with Miss Leverioh wearing a pretty black frock. Everyone was glad to see Mrs. Donegan back among the dancers; and Mrs Rom made her re appearance after her illness, which luckily was not of long duration. The Misses York were very much admired in their pretty frocks and with ribbons twisted in their fair hair; and Miss Rees could have filled her card many times over, as usual. Lord and Lady Vivian ware present with Miss Vivian wearing a delightful Empire frock of grey net, and the Countess von Hollen- stein was a most striking figure in black panne with a mass of waving white feathers in her coifare. The Misses Coles were in blue, as was Miss Feara her cousin, Miss Joseph wearing white net. Mrs. Howell wore a very handsome dress of satin bearing heavy applications of gold embroidery, and Miss McKellar had on a lovely frock of net and lace over palest pink em- broidered with tiny roses and relieved by lines of thin black. Mrs. Wyane was in one of her dainty frocks, a lovely shade of blue, with sleeves and chemisette of white, and blue bretelles across the shoulders, and Miss Blythe looked her stately best in vieux rose. Mrs. Chatterton Adams' dress of run with tiny frills of black, and Mrs. Peach was wearing a black lacs dress mounted over white. Mrs. Hunter also wore a magpie dress of black and white lace, and Mrs. Trafford Huteson was well turned ont as ever in a diamentee dress of yellow. Miss Coxon looked well in black, a colour which various others had also patronized.

Among others noticed during the evening were Mrs. Twomey, Mme Reyntians, Capt. and Mrs. Bayley, Mrs. Maclean, Mrs. Park Lyle, Dr. and Mrs. Phillips, the Messrs, and Miss de Bilinski, Mrs Stanley Bird. Mr. and Mrs. Frank Cook, the Messrs. Reid, Miss E herington Smith. Mr. Leslie Chafield, Mr. Gutman, Captain Stirling, Mr Pooley, Mr. Carter Wilson, Mr. Evans, and Mr. de Costa Andrada.

An extra item of interest was added to this evening by the presence of Miss Julie Critten, the clever palmist, who received her clients in one of the drawing rooms of the hotel. Many people have already taken advantage of this clever lady's services, and she is already being eagerly sought after. Miss Critten is making arrangements to receive her clinetele from time to time at the Savoy; and ere long it is expected that she will be in as great request in Cairo as she already is in Bond Street

div.head: OPERA HOUSE STRIKE.
div.p: The strike of the fourteen musicians at the Khedivial Opera House, Cairo, is the talk of the Capital. According to their version, they had counted on extra earnings to make ends meet, such, for instance, as a series of classic concerts at the Cercle Artistique. M. Poncet objected; whence the defection. The Cairote Press deals with the question from points of view characteristic of their respective opinion. "L'Egypte" is opposed to all arbitrary measures adopted against the strikers, and wonders that such incidents have not taken place before, in view of the antecedents of the direotor of the troupe.
"L'Orient" counsels moderation, and an appeal to the good offices of M. le Consul de France. It apmpathises with M. Poncet, and absolves him of all blame.
The "Journal da Caire" writes in the same strain.
The "Pyramides" is funny: "It is true that concord is not the most shining point of our musicians of the Opera. The Press has said so since the beginning of the season."

div.head:
OPERA IN CAIRO
KHEDIVIAL OPERA HOUSE.
div.p: "L'Africaine" afforded as all the keenest delight—quite apart from the undoubter merit of M. Meyerbeer's music. That charming vessel rolling, on its obvious pivots, even as the "Umberto Primo" rolls off the Cretan coast, the desolate mien of the crew huddled close to the bulwark-*, M. Mezy's sustained and despairing clutch at the mast, the while he shouted in sonorous frenzy, the wild incursion and alarm at the end —as of porters and boatmen in Naples harbour all was a joy, tinged with hope of "leave" to come or reminiscence of leave enjoyed. Even the cabin hangings which M. Fontaine brushed aside as he came and went were a memory of bathrooms and cabins, poignant and vivid. Yet no "Rubattino" or other boat could find its wild way to that weird island peopled with high- priests of the Brahmin persuasion, ballet- dancers, and, last of all, savages in sumptuous armour and European boots : those of course they had footed from the late departed crew of the ill-fated ship. Oh ! most exquisite island, most romantic ship!

The opera itself was performed much as usual, not without vigour and inaccuracy. Mile. Devillay, though, was really delicious. M. Fontaine seems to take to the fort tenor" parts, and enjoys his high notes. He is really a fine actor and musician. What a pity his voice is so displeasing ! He deserves a better fate. The orchestra, it appears, was "on strike," bat it was hard to notice any great difference, except that there were fewer and less prominent discords. M. Archimbaud would probably do quite well with two men and a boy, instead of the recalcitrant band he fails to control.

div.head: ABBAS THEATRE.
div.p: There were two really had episodes in "Mefitofele" : the chorus in the prologue was appalling, and in the second part Signora Orbellini gave an entirely wrong rendering of the 'Elena" music. The "La luna piena' should be, vocally, as cold, as dear, as rippling as the words are themselves. She treated it as she would have treated "La Tosca." However, her voice in itself is charming, the mistake was technical only. The only other fault was a certain want of cohesion in the garden scene; but Signor Lucenti saved the situation.

With these exceptions, it was really finely given. The conductor knows the opera, he handles his orchestra with a splendid keen vigour and intellectually, which one appre­ciates after Signor Archimbaud's listless,almost careless, treatment. Signor Battani, for all he has a bad cold, was exquisite; one could only just detect a certain slight huskiness ; and be seemed disinclined to take any notes higher than a natural He took them all the same once or twice. Signa. Fabris was nervous until the 3rd act. In that she was faultless; she sang with all the sweetness, passion, and dramatic power the scene requires. And Signor Lucenti ! He was not Signor Lucenti, he was Mifitofele incarnate. He conveyed every least shade of irony, sarcasm, scathing contempt that Bolto has put into the part; and his voice is a thing to dream of.—a superb full bass, resonant, never harsh, never a hair-breadth off the note. The part could not have been better sung. We have heard Signor Walter in the pain 1904-1905 and he evidently gave it finely this season at Alexandria. But Signor Lucenti puts his rendering, fine as it is, entirely into the shade. The prologue—where we forgot all the evil discords of the chorus, the "Fischio fischio" song in all its utter contempt for. God and man, the whole of the Brocken scene, the mocking, disgusted,disdainfal satire of "Questa Attica Terra," and the finale where the fiend descends, vanquished, but still great and contemptuous -one can find no words for these. I think if the Alexandria critic had heard it, he would hava changed his opinion of Bolto and his opera. Many, it is true, —many eminent musicians as well—think little enough of Bolto : they say he cannot orchestra, his effects shadowy, his scenes badly arranged, hie methods old-fashioned and poor. Bat the fact remains that "Mefistofele," for all it failed in 1868. is now given all over- Italy, as well as in London and Faris, and that 'Mefistofele" had as much influences as the work of Verdi himself on Italian opera. And really the beauty of the 3rd act, of the "Fisohio" song, of the Greek underworld scene, and the weird declamation on the Brocken, do deserve acknowledgment. Of course, Bolto under-orchestrates; he only wrote that one opera. How should he learn in one opera t< handle orchestras. He is an experimentalistwith no sort of wish to turn out 30 or 40 big pieces of work ; he is an analyst and a poet the whole of the libretto is taken from the original legend. He owes nothing to Gounod, and only a certain amount to Goethe himself his reading is totally different. All through the music, too, he experiments : he has special instruments and orchestration for Mefistofele- the "equilli" and certain pizzicato effects- and for Faust, usually violins and a certain soft and more melodious suavity. Of course, the whole work must be carefully given and properly staged. The Brocken scene, the Greek scene, the "Si gira, si gira" chorus, all have their absurd side; but so have many great operas. Anyone who heard M. Zuccani do the "Tannhauser" overture in waltz time will acknowledge that. Signor Lucenti, by the way is from La Scala, and is considered to be on of the three finest basses in Italy. The "Abbas is treating ns well, in that several others of the troupe are prominent performers at Milan, Naples, and other great opera towns.

div.head:
U S. A. AND JAPAN,
WILD TALK OF WAR.

div.p: Several American newspapers are printing the wildest articles regarding the prospect of a war with Japan, despite the assurance of Mr. Taft that such talk was absurd. It is alleged by them that Japan has practically presented an ultimatum. A circumstantial bat unauthorised report of President Roosevelt's speech to the Californian Congressmen, published represents the President as urging the neces ity for the immediate removal of the canses of friction without awaiting the decision of 'he Courts of the school questtion, on the ground that war with proud, brave Japan would be very different from war with Spain. They add that the Japanese are unlike Europeans, and would not exhanst the resources of diplomacy but strike quickly and without any warning.
The officials condemn the revival of the war talk as utterly unwarranted and tending to hinder a rational settlement, now in progress, being arrived at. ( Reuter)

div.head:
THE CAPITULATIONS.
"TIMES" ON THE RUSSIAN AFFAIR.

div.p: The the action of Lord Cromer in refusing to prevent the surrender of the Russian dynamiters, which, it says, is the only course possible while the Capitulations exist. The Capitulations, however, are a survival of a state of society which has completely passed away and the incident may cause the opponents of their Antichristian abolition to reflect.

Lord Crewe, speaking at Stoke-on-Trent said that the question of the reform of the House of Lords has not been shelved, the Government would soon made definite proposals with regard to the subject. (Reuter)

The results of 12 second ballots which took place in Germany yesterday are as follows . The Socialists had three losses, the Coiner, vatives one, the National-Liberals two gains, the Radicals one, and the Conservatives one.
Mr. Charier Thomas, Assistant Secretary, has been elected Permanent Secretary to the Admiralty, in succession to Sir E. MacGregor. (Reuter)

The Observer" understands that the proposed amalgamation of the Cape and East India squadrons has been dropped. This is believed to be partly in Consequence of the delay of the warships in reaching Kingston. (Reuter)
Seventeen deaths from plague have taken place since January 8. (Havas)
An avalanche has destroyed the casino of Bareges and twenty houses, many people being killed. (Havas}
Football. Rigby. Scotland beat Wales by 6 points to 3. ( Reuter)

div.head: FOOTBALL
div.p: RAILWAY INSTITUTE v A.O.C.

The above terms met in the return match on the Institute ground on Friday last, the first meeting having ended in a win for the Corps by 3 goals to one. The Institute had to rely on several reversing to the inability of some of the first team to turn out. The Corps, having won the toss, had the sun at their backs during the first half. The Institute from the kick off led a warm attack on the visitors' goal, the custodian saving from Esan in the first minute. The game, owing to the heavy state of the ground, was slow and uninteresting, the players finding great difficulty in keeping their feet. Still the home team soon settled down to sound work,only the fine defen sive work of the visiting backs keeping them out. At length Smith, on the left Receiving from Lloyd Jones, made a beautiful ran almost the whole length of the ground,and when within a few yards of the corner flag sent in a perfect centre, and Jones, pouncing on the ball, sent it flying into the net, giving the custodian no chance whatever. The interval arrived a few minutes later with the score 1 goal to nil in favour of the home team.

After the usual refresher the corps kicked off, but the home forwards soon settled down in the visitors' territory, Esau adding a second point soon after the resumption. Smith played , one of his best games at outside left, leading continuous raids on the visitors' fortress. Daring the biggest part of the second halt the homesters kept the visitors on the defen- sive, the custodial clearing time after time, and from one of Smith's centres Jones missed by inches only, heading outside when almost on the goal-line.

The homesters continued to have matters their own way, adding still another point from a weak clearance from the custodian Lloyd Jones secured and sending in a stiff shot towards the far post when one of the forwards rushed up and tumed the ball into the op posite corner of the net. From now to the end the soldiers had more of the game, event-ually scoring through Parrington from rut- side left, Davies being left helpless. The game ended shortly afterwards in a wall deserved win to the Institute team, who throughout played good, clean football. The visitors had a smart line of forwards quick on the ball, but very often they were beaten by the — home half backs, Jones Mahmoad and Miller who gave the opposing forwards no quarter Jones, besides playing a floe defensive game, gave Smith plenty of opportunities which he accepted. Hayes, as usual, was sound and along with Marshall saved Davies a good deal of work. The home custodian was in flue form, and was seldom in difficulties.

div.head: THE LATE DEAN BUTCHER.
div.p: Mrs. Butcher publishes the following letter in the last issue of the All Saints' parish magazine:—
CHURCH HOUSE,
ST. PAUL'S DAY January 1907.

My dear friends,—I take this opportunity of thanking you all most sincerely for your kind letters and words of sympathy with roe in my sorrow—which I know is also your sorrow. It is my chief comfort to receive such evidence of the way in which he was loved and appreciated by all those who knew him. It was a great disappointment to him not to go home ; he had looked forward with so much longing to a few years of rest and quiet in our Devonshire home. But in this as in all else* he resigned his own will without a murmur, when it was made dear to him that he was called upon to lay down his life and his charge together.

I thank you all for coming to his last 'Saturday," and for the thoughtful and reverent care with which everything was done. He would have liked the flowers too, they were like himself, of a rare and fragrant simplicity. He suffered much during the last week or two, particularly at night, but I need hardly tell you that his patience and courtesy never failed. Towards the end I was compelled to seek professional help at night, and when I came in to see him after one of those dreadful nights, his first words were always to enquire if I had slept; his second to tell me that the nurse was very tired, and must go at once to get a good rest.

He loved you all to the end. Almost his last words were a message to his "dear people." "Beloved, let us love one another." I believe they were to have been the closing words of his farewell sermon. He hoped for a long time that he might be able to speak to you again. After his death I found seven or eight newly-written sermons, ready for the time when he should ba well again. Mr. Burns will read these to you during the next few Sundays. There was also another one, of which he told me the substance, but of which I have not yet found any notes. It was to be a sermon specially delivered to the young Englishman in Egypt, and, if I cannot find it, I will at least write later the principal thing which he wanted to say to them. I have still some copies also of his published sermons, and if there are some who would like a copy, I should be glad to have their names and addresses, and will send the hooks from England.

He was no cloistered saint, but had been called to tread the ways of bitter sorrow. But he had a well spring of joy and peace which made everyone forget his troubles, even when they were at the worst, and he was always glad that it should be so. He loved merriment, and was always ready to laugh at himself, as well as with others. Love and joy were the keynotes of his life.
'Blessed are the dead which die in the Lord, that they rest from their labours, and their works do follow them."
"For the souls of the righteous are in the hand of God, there shall no torment touch them."
E. L. B.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY.

div.head: ARMY NOTES.
div.p: Lieutenant the Hononrable C. D. Biting, 2nd Battalion the Coldstream Guards. is about to retire from the Army. Mr. Baring served with the Coldstreamers throughout the South African War from the advance towards the relief of Kimberley till the last shot in May, 1902. He holds the Queen's medal with six clasps, and the King's medal with two clasps, for the notions of Belmont, Easlin, Modder River, Magersfontien, Vet River, Zend River, Johannesburg, Pretoria, Diamond Hill, Belfast, and the minor affairs in the Transvaal, Cape Colony and Orange River Colony,

Lieutenant W D. Kenny, 1st Battalion Royal Inn Mailing Fusiliers, Belfast, has been selected for service with the Egyptian Army, and proceeds forthwith to Cairo to report himself to the Sirdar. Lieutenant Kenny has worn the busby of the old 27th since March, 1901, when he was appointed to the regiment, from the unattached list. He is the son of Judge Kenny, and saw a good deal of service in the South African War, including the operations of 190102 in the Transvaal, Orange River Colony, and Cape Colony,for which he received the Queen's medal with five clasps.

Lieutenant N. A. Orr-Ewing, 2nd Battalion Soots Gaurds, of the well known Scottish military family, has also been selected for service with the Khedive's Army. Lieutenant Orr-Ewing has served in the Soots Guards since September, 1900, when he was appointed second lieutenant from the 4th Battalion Argyll and Sutherland Highlander?, then in South Africa. He shared in the operations in Cape Colony and Orange River Colony (Queen's medal with two clasps). He is the senior subal- tern in the regiment.

When the 1st Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, Belfast, and the 1st Battalion Connanght Rangers, Mullingar, leave those places for Crete and Malta respectively, their details will be sent to Tidworth Camp,Salisbury Plain, to join the Provisional Battalion. Tidworth is about the dreariest station in the United Kingdom during the winter months.

div.head: PROSPECTUS
div.p: This Company has been formed for the objects set on in the Company's Memorandum of Association, including the acquisition of the clientele and business of the partnership "en commandite" carried on at Cairo and Alexandria under the style of A. Lunghis & Co. as from the 1st January 1907, the carrying on of the business of stock, share and produce brokers, and the undertaking of Exchange, Bourse, Financial and Commercial operations and transactions of all kinds.

The Company intends forthwith to commence business at Cairo and Alexandria and for that purpose has entered into arrangements for the conduct of its affairs on the Boorses. at Cairo and Alexandria and will enter into such other arrangements as may be necessary.
The Directors and friends have subscribed the Company's Memorandum of Association for 97000 shares.

The Vendors, Messrs. Achille Lunghis & Co, show their confidence in the Company's future by not only accepting the whole of the purchase consideration payable to them entirely in folly paid shares and subscribing for 20,000 shares by the Company's Memorandum of Association, but they have also agreed to deposit with the Company 50,000 fully paid shares to the intent that the said 50,000 shares shall not be sold or dealt with by them as to 30,00 daring the period of three years from the date of the Company's incorporation, and as to 20,000 during the period of one year from the same date.
The whole of the purchase consideration, namely £36,000, to be paid in fully paid shares represents the agreed value of the goodwill.
The Company has secured the services of Mr. ACHILLE LUNQHIS as its Managing Direotor for a period of five years from the date of the incorporation of the Company.
The services of MR. ARTHUR SPAGNOLO, until recently 'fonde de pouvoirs" of the Credit Lyonnais at Alexandra, have also been remained for a like period, as Assistant Manager.
The Articles of Association contain the following provisions:

94 As remuneration for their services the directors (other than the Managing Director)shall be paid at the rate of £100 per annum for each ordinary Director and at the rate of £250 per annum for the Chairman.
Provided, nevertheless, that if in any year a dividend at the rate of at least £6 per annum is not paid, the remuneration of the Directors shall be at one half of the before mentioned rate.

In addition to the aforesaid remuneration, each Direotor shall also receive such farther sum (if any) as the Company in general meeting may from time to time determine. An alternate Direotor appointed under Article 9 hereof shall not as snob be entitled to any remuneration.

95. Any Direotor may be employed by or hold any office of profit under the Company, except that of Auditor of the Company, and may act either personally or as a member of the firm for, or render any professional services to the Company, and may receive remuneration from the Company for so doing in addition to any remuneration payable to him as a Direotor. If any Direotor, being willing, shall be called upon to perform extra servicer or to make any special exertions in going or residing abroad, or in negotiating or carrying into effect any contract or arrangement by the Company or otherwise for any of the purposes of the Company, or act as Trustee for the Company or its debenture holders, and shall do so,the Company may remunerate each Direotor either by a fixed sum or a percentage of profits, or otherwise, as may be determined by the Directors, and such remuneration may ba either in addition to or in substitution for his remuneration above provided. If any Direotor shall be appointed to represent the Company as a Director of any subsidiary or other Company in which the Company shall be interested, he shall, unless otherwise agreed, be entitled to retain the remuneration attaching to such Directorship for his own use.

div.head: CONTRACTS.
div.p: The following contracts have been entered into:—

An agreement dated the 20th day of November 1906 between the members of the partnership firm "en commandite" A. Lunghis & Co. namely, Achille Lunghis, Geo Miniakis, Constantin Renos, Maria Kavaffi, Michael Salvago, of the first part, Cleon Lunghis of the second part and Charles H. Lloyd of the 3rd part whereby the said firm A Lunghis & Co. agreed to sell to the Company its business as a going concern including the goodwill, pending contracts, and agreements for tenancy, as at the 1st January 1907.

An agreement dated the 27th December 1906 between the Company and Mr. Achille Lunghis providing for the appointment of the latter as Managing Direotor of the Com- pany for a period of five years at a salary of 1,000 pounds per annum and a percentage of 3% of the gross profits of the Company remaining in each year after deduction of the general expenses.
An Agreement dated the 27th day of December 1906 between the Company and Arthur Spangolo providing for the appointment of the latter as Assistant Manager and for his remuneration as such.

div.head: GENERAL
div.p: The amount fixed by the Articles as to minimum subscription upon which the Directors may proceed to allotment is £10 000.
The preliminary expenses payable by the Company are estimated at £3,000.

By the Articles the Directors have power to increase the capital of the Company by the creation of new shares of such an amount as they may deem expedient not exceeding, with the original capital, £1,000,000.
A copy of the Memorandum of Association which forms part of this prospectus is endorsed hereon.
Applications for shares should be made on the accompanying form, and forwarded with cheque for the amount payable on application to the Company's Bankers.

If no allotment is made the application money will be returned in full, and where the number of shares allotted is less than that applied for, the surplus will be credited in reduction of the amount payable on allotment, and any excess will be returned to the applicant.
Failure to pay any instalment when doe will render the previous payments liable to be forfeited.
The above mentioned contracts or copies thereof, together with a print of the Company's Memorandum and Articles of Association, may be inspected at the offices of the Company in Cairo and Alexandria.
Copies of the Prospectus and application forms can be obtained at the said offices of the Company, or from the Bankers.
Dated this 22nd day of January 1907.
Davies
Bryan
& Co.

div.head: BULLETIN DB LA BOURSE
div.p: Bien que l'attention ait retenue ce matin par les reglements de fin de moir, il y a eu cependant un mouvewent dechanges assez actif en Nile Land, Nungovich Hotels Ritz, Arditi et Levico.

Las Ritz s'avancent a 1 25/32. s Arditi sont demandes a 1 11/32 les actions et 22 livres lew parts de fondatenrs. La Lunghis s'insorit a 1 11/32 acheteurs egalemente et la Levico a 15/16 L'United a peu traitee. Elle cote environ 1 7/32 et 9 livres la part de fondatenr.

La Nile Land, aprez avoir depase 23 livres oldtore 22 5/8 3/4. Li hausse et attribute a la vente par cette societe de sa propriete de Kasr-el-Aly sur lsqaelle elle aurait realise on enorme benefice. Il s'agirait de 80.00O metres achetes a 2 livres environ et vendus a 15 livres le metre.
Demande croissante en Union Funciere qui savance a 6 3/8 achetenra. Das cours beancoup plus eleves sont preveus breve echeance

En hausse egalemente la Privlege Biere d' Alexandria 230, l'Obligition Credit Foncier a 348 l'anoienne et 272 1/2 la nouveile, la Banque d'Athenes a 136 1/2, les Nungovich a 24 3/8. la Delta Land a 4 19/32, la Land Bank a 9 3/16 la Buildinig Lands a 6 5/16, et la Port Said Salt a 15/6.

Par contre, la National Bank flechit a 28 1/16, les Privileges a Tramways a 199 et les Dividends a 360, lea Privileges Bieree da Caire a 128, la Salt and Soda a 22/9, les Lots Taros k 156 la Cassa di Sonto a 283, l'Ur- bair e a 7 15/16, et la part de fondatenr Comp- toir a 95.
Sur le rests aucan changement a signaler. La tendance pour la semaine parait etre excellente, sauf evenement imprevu.

Les souscripteurs qui n'auraient '.pas libéré leurs titres de 2 L.E. a la répartition seront passibles d'intérêts de retard a 9% l'an depuis cette date jusqu'au jour de , la libération. L'admission a la cote d63 Bourses du Caire et d'Alexandrie sera demandée.

div.head: PROSPECTUS
div.p: THE EGYPTIAN ECONOMICAL RESIDENCES Cy a pour objet : la construction, 1'expleitation, a location, la datation ou prise a bail, l\chat, la vente au comptant ou par paiements échelonnés, pour son compte personnel on en participation, la gérance d'habitations a bon marohé ou autres ; l'achat, la vente de terrains rnraox ou urbains ainsi que toutes opérations commerciales, indnstrielles on financières se rattachant de près on de loin au but social tant en son nom personnel qa'en participation et cela dans la pins large conoeption de l'idée Bans que l'énoncé précédent puisse être considéré comme restrictif.

La Société vient d'acheter dans des conditions de prix et de paiement très avantageuses environ 9920 mètres carrés de terrain à bâtir sis entre le Z ber et la Route de l'Abbassieh, au point connu sous le nom d'ancien abattoir, divisés en plusieurs lots.

Elle a acquis aussi avec grandes facilités de paiement, la propriété connue sons le nom de Palais Yeghen d'nne contenance de 20,000 mètres carrés environ sis à Serooghieb, dans un des centres les pins populeux da Caire, aux environs de Khan Kbahl, de la Sekka Guédida, du Monski, de la Place Mansour Pacha, da Goavernorat et des Tribunaux Mixtes, presque en bordure du Boulevard Mohammed Aly.

Les employés des Banqaes et du Commerce y trouveront aux environs des lieux de lear travail des logements confortables dont la proximité leur évitera des pertes de temps sans les obliger a des dépenses de transport.
La démolition des énormes bâtisses qui constituent le Palais Yeghen et la vente des matériaux en provenant seront mises immédiatement en adjudication.

La Société se propose d'édifier ensuite, des constructions de plusieurs étages divisés en nombreux appartements composés de pièces judicieusement distribuées, ventilées, éo'ailées et assainies par l'adoption de tous les principes de l'hygiène la mieux comprise. Ces appartements pourront être cédés en location a des prix modestes, a partir de 3 L.E. par mois suivant les étages et le nombre de pièces dont ils se composeront.

Mr. Margissoff Bey. Ingénieur au Caire, expert prèsMes Tribunaux Mixtes, chargé par la Société de visiter le terrain, et d'en apprécier la valeur, a déclaré dans son rapport d'expertise que la vente par lots peut rapporter nn minimum de 75% de bénéfice. Nous avons lieu de oroire que cette prévision sera' dépassée de beaucoup.

Mr. Mariohal, Ingénieur, expert près les Tribunaux Mixtes d'Alexandrie, également consulté, a conclu après étude sur les lieux, que les capitaux employés en constructions économiques élevées sur ce terrain pourraient obtenir un intéiêt de 15% l'an net.

div.head: EXTRAITS LES STATUTS.
div.p: ARTICLE 43.
Sur le bénéfices nets et annuels il sera prélevé :
Ie 5% pour la formation du tends de réserve. Ce prélèvement cessera d'être obligatoire Ion que le fonds atteindra le cinquiènde du Capital 8ocial.
Ie 5% pour la formation du tends de réserve. Ce prélèvement cessera d'être obligatoire Ion que le fonds atteindra le cinquiènde du Capital Social.
L'excédent sera réparti comme mit :
25% au Conseil d'Administration.
75% aux actionnaires.
ARTICLE 6.

Les appels de fonds qu'il y aura lieu de faire sur les'pon émîtes ru a émettre oltérieu rement seront réglés par le Conseil d'Administiaticn qui en déterminera l'époque ainsi que le mode et le lieu de paiement.
Tonte somme dont le paiement est retardé porte de plein droit en faveur de la Société» intérêt a 9% 1 an a partir du jour de l'ex'gibilité sans demande en justice.

A défaut de versement a l'échéance, la Société a droit, un mois après publication des numéros des titres en retard dans un journal désigné pour les annonces judiciaires an Caire, de faire procéder a la vente, en bloc on en détail, aêmea des époques successives, des aotions a la Bourse d'Alexandrie on du Caire, par courtiers ou agents de charrie, pour le compte et aux risques et périls des retardataires sans mise en demeure ni formalités judiciaires.
Les titres ainsi vendus deviennent nuis de plein droit et il en est délivré aux acquéreurs de nouveaux soas les mêmes numéros.
Tout titre qui ne porte pas mention réguliè e du versement des sommes exigibles oesse d'être i égociable.
1/68 mesures autorisées rar le présent art cle ne font pas obstacle a l'éxeroice simultané par la Société des moyens ordinaires de droit.

Les prix provenant de la vente, dédaction faite des frais, appartiennent a la Société et s'imputent, dans les termes de droi*, sur ce qui est dû par, l'actionnaire exproprié qui reste passible de la différence s'il y a déficit, mais qui profite de 1 excédent s il en existe.
Les demandes d'actions doivent être faites snr formule oi jointe et envoyées accompagnées do déiôt a :
Monsieur le Directeur de Is CASSA DI SCONTO E DI RISPARMIO
Au Caire ou à Alexandrie.
La répartiton sera faite au Caire par les soins de la CASSA DI SCONTO E DI RISPARM ta des souscriptions.
Cagoùle nù auoune action ne serait allouée, le déjôt sera remboursé intégralement et au aul'aotions allouées serait inférieur a celui demandé, la différence sera appliquée dû par le sousoripteor.

div.head: THE ARTESIAN BORING AND PROSPEGTING Cy.
div.p: Société Anonyme Egyptienne — Siégé Social au Caire.

suivant decision de l'Assemblee Generale Extraordianaire du 12 Janvier 1907
Sont offertes a la Souscription Publique:
10,000 Actions Nouvelles de Lstg, 5 chacune
aux conditions suivantes
1. —TAUX D'EMISSION : ISTQ. 5.5.0 ah. Par action, soit avec une prime de 5 ah. Qui sera portée an compte de réserve, déduction faite des frais d'émission.
2. —VERSEMENT A LA SOUSCRIPTION 10 SH. et à la répartition Lstg. 1, soit an quart Et prime de 5 ah.
3. —JOUISSANCE : 1er AVRIL 1907 ; (il sera servi ao les montants versés an intérêt a Raison de 6 % l'an dès le 15 février an 31 Mars 1907, date de clôture de l'exercice annuel.)
4. — Il Ruera distribuer une coupure de PART DE FONDATEURS pour opaque 5 actions De capital allouées aux Souscripteurs on remise en échange.

5. —Les VERSEMENTS ULTÉRIEURS seront appelés par décisions du Conseil d'Administration jour préavis d'non mois, an far et à mesure des besoins de la Société, par appels de Lstg. 1.5.0., soit d'non quart par action, à intervalles de deux mois an 'moins.
6. —11 est réservé aux porteurs d'actions anciennes un DROIT DE PREFERENCE pour la "souscription à raison de deux actions nouvelles pour chaque action ancienne.

N.B. Il avait été orées lors Je la fondation delà Société en 1904, 200 Actions de Dividende,' soit Parts de fondateurs, sans désignation de valeur, attribuées aux fondateurs, en proportion de lent « souscription aux premières autos de capital. D'après le Statuts primitifs les bénéfices nets après prélèvement de 6 % pour les Aoutions de C'spral étaient répartis comme suit : 50 % aux Actions de Capital, 50% aux Actions de Dividende.

Va l'augmentationdu Capital. ' les porteurs de Parts de Fondateurs ont unanimement consentis 1 à réduire 4P, la participation des Parts de Fondateurs dans les bénéfices 2 à abandonner or partie de leurs Parts an profit des souscripteurs du nova- veau capital émis.
Ces Parti out été en conséquence divisées en Centièmes et 1 sera attribué une de ces coupures 'par chaque 5 actions allouées aux souscripteurs.
Lts souscriptions feront reçues accompagnées du versement de 10 sh. par titre à L'ANEHO EGYPTIEN BANK LIMITED au Caire ou à Alexandrie
les 4, 5 et 6 Février 1907 de 9 heures à midi et de 3 à 5 heures

An cas Cu les demandes dépasseraient le nombre des actions mises à la disposition du Public, le Conseil d'Administration re réserve tous pouvoirs pour la répartition. Toutefois l'allocation ne se fera que par Oit q actions ou mull piles d'oint q actions. L'ex cèdent des sommes déposées erra rembourser dès la répartition opérée.

Le droit de préférence réservé aux porteurs d'actions anciennes s'exercera sur pré sensation de leurs titres à l'appui de leur souscription ou d'n ne déclaration de dépôt délivrée par une banne en vue de l'exercice du droit de préférence.

En outre, il est réservé aux port » or d'ariennes actions, le droit d'échanger leurs actions à raison d'une action anosienne contre quatre nouvelles libérées d'un quart avec coupures de Parts afférentes, soit une pour 5 actions nouvelles.

MM. les portera d'actions anciennes qui n'utiliseraient pas ce droit d'échange sont de mêmes invités à présenter leurs titres à l'Anglo Egyptien-Bank Ltd. pour l'apposition du timbre mentionnant l'augmentation du capital-actions.
La cote a la Bourse sera demandée aussitôt que la répartition de la nouvelle émission aura été faite.
Un courtage de 1 schelling par action attribuée sera payé pour toute souscription portant le timbre des banques ou courtiers.
Les Statuts de la Société sont à la disposition du Public au Siège Social au Caire, 28, 8haria-el-Manakb.

Les souscriptions doivent être faites sur la formule oie jointe et parvenir à L'MANOLO- EGYPTIEN BANK LTD. AVANT MERCREDI LE 6 FEVRIER A 5 H. DU SOIR, sinon elles ne seront pas prises en considération.

div.head: PROSPECTUS
div.p: FONDATION DE LA SOCIÉTÉ —La Société Anonyme TUB ARTESIEN BORING & PROSPECTING CO. a été autorisée par Décret Khédivial do 15 Mai 1904.

OBJET. —Elle a pour bot : le forage et l'installation de puits dits artésiens, soit pour l'alimentation en eau potable des villes et des particuliers, soit pour l'irrigation des terres ; l'acquisition de terrains susceptibles d'être cultivés grève à l'irrigation artésienne et antres ; l'exécution de toutes sortes de sondages et forages profonds pont recherches minières ; l'obtention et l'exploitation de toutes concessions de recherches.
TRAVAUX EXECUTÉS :

A) IRRIGATIONS. —La Société a exécuté depuis sa fondation non grand nombre d'installations d'irrigation artésienne, et elle a en mains pour plus de L.E 20,010 de nouveaux contrats, dont plusieurs concernent des installations devant fournir chacune environ 30,000 m3 d'eau par jour. Le nombre toujours croissant de com-mandes de puits artésiens provient :

1° de ce que l'irrigation artésienne permet d'éviter les inconvénients don Système des rotations ; 2" de la mise en culture de nombreux terrains auxquels fait défaut toute irrigation par l'eau du Nil.

B) ALIMENTATIONS EN EAU POTABLE—La Société a achevé plusieurs installations en eau potable pour le compte d'administrations Gouvernementales et de particuliers, entre antres celle de la ville de Khartoum. Elle vient d'être chargé de l'ex option de la partie bydranlique pont les fournitures en eau potable des villes de Menon et Zagazig.

C) FORAGES PROFONDS. —La Société possède des outillages à vapeur pour sondages et forages à grande profondeur. Un forage a 800 pieds a été fait à Port Soudan et non antre de 500 à 1,000 pieds de profondeur est en osons d'exponction dans la i même localité. Le Gouvernement a également chargé la 8ociété de faire à Mers I Matrouh an sondage de 700 pieds pont recherche d'eau douce. Un sondage de Rebroche a été exécuté à 400 pieds de profondeur pour le compte de l'Egyptien Coal Syndicate.

CONCESSIONS. —La Société a obtenu du Gouvernement une concession de 5.100 1 feddans de terrains onltivables dans le district de Mers Matrouh et de 12,000 I de terrain a tir le long du port de omette même localité. 1 Cette concession est appelée an pin grand avenir par site de l'achèvement : prochain don chemin de fer construit par Son Altesse le Khédive sur la côte Ouest d'Alexandrie.

RESULTATS OBTENUS. —Il a été distribué 6% pour le 1er exercice ; 9 % pont le j , 2me après amortissement de tons frais de premier établissement et de 20 % sur La valeur don matériel. Les comptes arrêtés provisoirement an 3" Novembre 1906, T accusent déjà pont les 8 premiers mois don 3me exercice, actuellement en osons Et se terminant le 31 Mars 1907, on bénéfice de plus de 20 % du capital, d'endoton faite de tous irais d'exploitation et d'administration. Les affaires actuellement J oncles, dont la pins grande partie ne s'achèveront qu'au cours de l'exercice proChain, assurent d'ores et déjà à elles seules non bénéfice suffisant pont rémunérer Le nouveau capital émis.
I AUGMENTATION DU CAPITAL. —Les fonds provenant de la nouvelle émission seront affectés pricipaltmeot à :
1. —La mise en valeur de la concession de Mers Matrouh.
2. —L'acquisition et la mine en valeur de terrains susceptibles d'être exploités An moyen d'irrigation artésienne.

3. —L'extension des entreprises de forages profonds pont reoherôbea minières. I La Société a déjà fait ses preuves. Les résultats qu'elle a pu obtenir ave 1 Non capital aussi minime que relai dont elle a disposé jusqu'à présent, montrent B one qu'elle pourra réaliser lorsque ses resouries loi permettront de porter sonaotivité.
Dans les diverses branches que ses Statuts l'autorisent à exploiter.

5. —Il est réservé aux porteurs d'actions anciennes un droit de préférence à la souscription à raison de DEUX ACTIONS NOUVELLES POUR CINQ ACTIONS ANCIENNES.
Aucune fraction ne sera considérée comme valable.

Les souscriptions seront reçues, accompagnées du versement de L E. 1. Par titre, par THE NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT. AU CAIRE et à ALEXANDRIE, les 4, 5, et 6 Février 1S07, de 9 heures à midi et de 3 à 5 heures p.m.
Le droit de préférai ce réservé aux porteurs d'actions anciennes s'exercera sn présentation de leurs titres à l'appui de leur souscription, et sn les actions entièrement libérées.
Les actions non souscrites par les propriétaires d'actions existantes seront réparties parmi le » autres souscripteurs d'actions.
Des Bulletin de Souscription sont à la disposition du Publico à la National Bank of Egypt.

div.head: Daira Khalsa de S. A. le Khédive
div.p: AVIS
La Daira Kassaï mot en vente une batteuse mécanique à l'état neuf de 4 pieds et demi avec tous ses accessoires et pièces de rechange.
Les personnes qui désirent concourir à l'achat de ladite batteuse peuvent la visiter au T'entiche de Koubbeh.
Les offres devront être adressées à S.E. le Directeur Général de la Daira Khalsa et présentées sous pli cacheté accompagnée d'un cautionnement de 10 % ad valorem.
La Daira procédera à l'ouverture des offres Dimanche 10 Février 1907. Elle se réserve le droit d'accepter ou de refuser n'importe quelle offre.

div.head: NOTICE
div.p: There will be two appointments for Doctors in the Sudan Medical Department made about April next.
Candidates should forward all testimonials to the Director Sudan Medical Department, Khartoum.
Information as to age, qualifications, engagements since qualifications, is required.
Candidates should be about 25 years old and unmarried and should have a good knowledge of English and Arabic. Egyptians will be preferred.
Salary to commence at the rate of L.E. 20 per member, eligible for increase after two years' satisfactory service.
Applicants should be prepared to appear for interview about the 2nd week in March 1907, in Cairo.
Appointment for probation 3 months, afterwards for a year before being permanently admitted into the Government service.
Sudan Agency,
War Office, Cairo.
Alexandria, January 17, 1907.

div.head: General Post Office.
div.p: An examination will be held at the Alexandria Post Office at 9 a.m. on the 11th February next, and at the Cairo Post Office at 9 a.m. on the 14th February next, for the purpose of filling vacancies of clerk on L.E. 5 per month and of apprentice on L.E. 3, according to the ability of the candidate.

Intending candidates must be of Egyptian nationality and 18 years old, and must forward their applications to his Excellency the Post- master General, General Post Office, Alexandria, made out in their own handwriting on Ministerial Form No. 167 C.G. not later than the 9th February for Alexandria and the 12th for Cairo.
The following must accompany this Form:
1° Primary Education Certificate obtained within the last three years.
2° A Certificate showing that the Candidate has paid his military exemption fee or that he has not yet been selected for conscription.
If the candidate is attached to another Government Administration, he must obtain written permission to attend the examination from his chief and forward it together with the other documents.
